questiontext.text:
An item of inventory was purchased for $500. It is expected to be sold for $1,200 although $250 will need to be spent on it in order to achieve the sale. To replace the same item of inventory would cost $650.

At what value should this item of inventory be valued in the financial statements?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=500:0}

generalfeedback.text: Inventory should be valued at the lower of cost and net realisable value. Net realisable values $1,200 - $250 = $950, with cost of $500 the lower of the two possibilities.

questiontext.text:
Shah Rukh's financial year end is 30 June 20X6. However, the annual inventory count took place on 7 July 20X6. The inventory value on that date was $38,950. During the period from 30 June 20X6 to 7 July 20X6, the following transactions took place:

$
Sales6,500
Purchases4,250

Sales are made at a mark-up on cost of 25%.
What was Shah Rukh's inventory valuation at 30 June 20X6?

generalfeedback.text:
$
Value at 7 July 20X638,950
Sales since year end (100/125 x $6,500)5,200
Purchase since year end(4,250)
Value at 30 June 20X639,900

questiontext.text:
Jason is a book wholesaler. On each sale, commission of 4% is payable to the selling agent. The following information is available in respect of total inventories at the year-end of three of the most popular titles:

Cost ($)Selling price ($)
Henry VII - Shakespeare2,2802,900
Dissuasion - Jane Armstrong-Siddeley4,0804,000
Pilgrim's Painful Progress - John Bunion1,2801,300

What was the total value of these items of inventory in Jason's statement of financial position?

generalfeedback.text:
The net realisable value of inventory items is the selling price less the 4% commission payable.
NRV
$		Lower of cost or NRV
$
Henry VII2,7842,280
Dissuasion3,8403,840
John Bunion1,2481,248
7,368

questiontext.text:
An organisation had inventory at 1 July of 15 units purchased at a unit cost of $3.00. The following inventory subsequent movements occurred:

3 July 20X4: 5 units sold at $3.30 each
8 July 20X4: 10 units bought at $3.50 each
12 July 20X4: 8 units sold at $4.00 each

What was the cost of the closing inventory on a FIFO basis?

generalfeedback.text:
$
10 items at $3.50 each35
2 items at $3 each6
Cost on a FIFO basis is41

questiontext.text:
Michael has closing inventory which cost $38,750. This includes some damaged items which cost $3,660. It will cost Michael $450 to repair these. Michael will be able to sell them for $1,500 after the repairs are completed.

What is the correct value of Michael closing inventory?

generalfeedback.text: The damaged items have a cost of $3,660, but a net realisable value of only $1,050 ($1,500 - $450). Therefore, the cost of the inventory needs to be written down by $2,610 ($3,660 - $1,050). The inventory will then have a correct value of $36,140 ($38,750 - $2,610).

questiontext.text: Which method of inventory valuation is used when issues are assumed to be taken from inventory in the order in which they were received?

generalfeedback.text: ERROR No explaination found. Please add an explaination later.

questiontext.text:
When Suraya prepared the draft accounts, closing inventory at a value of $21,870 was included. Suraya has just discovered that some items valued at $2,150 had not been included in the valuation.

How will net profit and net assets be affected when the inventory valuation is corrected?

generalfeedback.text: Closing inventory reduces the cost of sales figure. If the value of closing inventory is increased, cost of sales will be reduced and net profit will be increased. Net assets will also increase.

answer.text: Net profit Reduced by $2,150; Net assets Reduced by Â£2,150
Net profit Reduced by $2,140; Net assets Increased by $2,150
Net profit Increased by $2,150; Net assets Reduced by $2,150
Net profit Increased by $2,150; Net assets Increased by $2,150

questiontext.text:
Nadine made a mistake when performing calculations which resulted in the value of closing inventory at 30 April 20X4 being overstated by $900. The value was calculated correctly at 30 April 20X5.

What was the effect of the error on the profit reported in Nadine's accounts for each of the two years?

generalfeedback.text: The over-valuation in 20X4 will boost profits in 20X4 by reducing cost of sales. However, the opening inventories in the following year will be overstated increasing cost of sales and reducing profits.

questiontext.text:
Remy is an antiques dealer. Remy's inventory includes a clock which cost $15,800. Remy expects to spend $700 on repairing the clock which will mean that it could then be sold for $26,000.

At what value should the clock be included in Remy's inventory?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=15800:0}

generalfeedback.text: Inventories are valued at the lower of cost and net realisable value. The cost of repairing the clock will reduce the expected profit, but the clock's net realisable value is still greater then cost and so no reduction in value is needed.

questiontext.text:
JOJO Co has just published its financial statements, which show a gross profit for the year of $6.5 million. A major error in the inventory valuation has just been discovered. The opening inventory was overstated by $1.3 million, and the closing inventory has been understated by $1.6 million.

What should be JOJO Co's correct gross profit for the year?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=9400000:0}

What is the unit cost of the following item?
$
Raw materials5.00
Labour3.00
Manufacturing overheads1.00
Variable administrative overheads2.50

generalfeedback.text: Administrative costs are not included in the statement of financial position valuation of an item in the inventory.

questiontext.text:
Hewlett made an error when calculating the value of closing inventory, which resulted in an overvaluation of inventory.

Raw materials5.00
Labour3.00
Manufacturing overheads1.00
Variable administrative overheads2.50

How will Hewlett's net profit for the year and net assets at the end of the year be affected by this error?

generalfeedback.text: ERROR No explaination found. Please add an explaination later.

questiontext.text:
What is the net realisable value of the following item?
$
Selling price20.00
Packaging costs2.00
Delivery costs3.00
Licence fee paid after delivery2.50

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=12.5:0}

generalfeedback.text: Assuming that all the costs would be incurred by the seller (and not the customer) the net realisable value is $20 - $2 - $3 - $2.50 = $12.50.

questiontext.text:
Diesel fuel included in the inventory of an entity at 1 November 20X7 was $12,500 and, of this, invoices were still to be received for deliveries which cost $1,700. During the year to 31 October 20X8, diesel fuel bills of $85,400 were paid, and a delivery of diesel fuel costing $1,300 had yet to be invoiced. At 31 October 20X8, the inventory of diesel fuel was valued at $9,800.

What amount is to be charged to the statement of profit or loss for the year to 31 October 20X8 for diesel fuel?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=87700:0}

generalfeedback.text:
$
Payments for purchases85,400
Less: Invoices for opening inventory-1,700
Plus: Invoices due for fuel purchased1,300
Purchases85,000

$
Opening inventory12,500
Purchases85,000
Closing inventory-9,800
Cost of fuel used in the year - profit or loss87,700

UnitsUnitsUnits
